text: Hello there everybody and welcome to
integrate art, sound and code into
Unreal Engine with Perforce P4. Uh,
cool. Welcome. So today I'm going to try
to go through kind of a variety of
things. So depending where you are in
your journey of working with artists and
working with Unreal and Perforce,
hopefully there will be something for
you in here. So to start off, I'm going
to talk a little bit about just general
ideas of what is a good pipeline.
Talking about some stream setups with P4
as well as folder setups. Uh talk a
little bit about virtual streams, which
are one of my favorite things and I
think they're not used as much as they
should be. Uh, and then the those last
two there are all going to be going
through a demo of actually working with
some artists on a little small project
in Unreal Engine. So, that'll probably
be the the bulk of it will be going
through that demo. And with that, I'm
emphasizing more the experience of the
artists in this case. And I'm not doing
a lot of super fancy stuff in the
engine. Um because I think that's often
the piece that's missing is how do we
get the artists involved in this
workflow? How do we make it so they feel
comfortable contributing things to
version control so that the developers
can get access to their files and they
can be part of the pipeline instead of
this kind of separate thing which is how
artists can end up feeling sometimes.
I have a resources page here. If you
scan this um I have some links that I
will mention during the presentation.
Those will all be here. I'll show this
one more time at the end as well. Um,
but I'll talk about some things that
I've put up on GitHub that are available

Okay. So, the epic battle of artists
versus organization. So, on the one
hand, artists, they don't learn version
control. And I know this because I was
one of them. I think I still am one of
them. uh that when I was a VFX artist
and when I was a musician, never once
heard about version control. It was not
a concept anyone talked about. Uh and
when I did start learning it, it broke
my brain a little bit because it wasn't
something I'd thought about. It was a
different way of thinking about how to
manage versions of files. And then on
the other hand, having a lack of
structure, which is how a lot of art
teams end up, is painful. It makes it
easy to lose things, forget things,
communicating changes and file paths via
Slack or Discord or email or or when I
worked on the pipeline team at the VFX
studio, we had to write all of this
custom in-house stuff to keep track of
paths for people because we didn't just
have version control.
So, on the one hand, we don't learn it.
On the other hand, it's it's painful.
And so, is there a better way? How can
we bridge this gap? How can we make
version control beneficial for artists
and how do we avoid some of that pain of
disorganization?
So I gave some thought to my you know 10
years of experience or so developing
pipelines in VFX and then also working
with gaming studios for the last four
years with Perforce and
looking at what is it that makes a
pipeline good and one is that it's it
brings everyone together so everyone's
on the same page. It's unified. It's
clear. So it's no more complicated than
necessary. And as a pipeline developer,
uh, often our definition of necessary
might be more complicated than other
people would like, but trying to keep
that in mind of like how can we keep
this simple? How can we keep it
straightforward? Uh, and then it needs
to be adaptable. If it's too rigid, then
a new project comes along where you have
to do something different and you're out
of luck.
So starting off with what does it mean
to be unified? There's two approaches to
this. So one is perforce right is if
everyone all of your artists your game
designers your coders are all storing
their versions in the same place then
you have that single source of truth but
even within that how do you store stuff
in your perforce server right how do you
store things in your P4 server and so
for that um I wanted to point out this
tip that was from uh this talk last year
setting up in Unreal Engine Studio the
epic If you haven't watched this talk,
it's on YouTube. It's amazing.
Definitely go check it out. Uh I've
linked to it in that resources page. And
one of the important notes is this. Most
studios, including Epic Games, commit
features and content directly into
Maine. So this means everyone's
submitting their content into the same
place. And it means that you encounter
problems and challenges sooner rather
than working in isolation and then
having a big headache trying to merge
all of that later on. So with this idea,
you know, Epic has built a lot of their
tooling around that concept of how can
we work together better all in one
branch, all in one stream. And then that
also lets you take advantage of
exclusive locking in Perforce so that
two people aren't working on the same
file at the same time. And with Unreal
Engine files, you can't merge those. So
this saves you a lot of pain, a lot of
wasted work.
So I want to show you my example of my
ideal stream setup in P4.
It's like that. So I think that the key
here is starting with just the one
mainline stream that everybody works in
should be your default thought. Now,
realistically, studios will have much
more complicated setups than that, but I
think it's important to approach that of
making more streams as you need them and
not starting off with a lot more
complexity because every step that
involves merging and branching is just
more overhead for whoever is in charge
of your server. So, if you can keep it
simple, that's great. So, is it unified?
Heck yes. Is it clear? Yep. You just
work in this one place. And is it
adaptable? Well, let's take a look at
that.

that there's this little field, you can
see down in the the bottom left there,
this uh ignored field. I can highlight
it like this. uh you can put paths in
there in your stream and then even if
you don't have a P4 ignore file set up,
those will still be ignored and it's
impossible for anyone to submit those
when they're working in this stream. So
I always recommend at least doing this
bare minimum of your saved folder, your
intermediate folder, and your derived
data cache. And if you have Mac users,
this DS store, just put those in the
ignored on your stream just so you don't
ever end up with those in your version
control because that's just a huge pain
to clean up. Uh, and then I would also
put a P4 ignore file in the root of my
workspace so that I'm also getting that.

Okay, so Epic has this thing that I
think they call it the native folder
structure. And what this means is that
you have your engine folder next to your
project folder. And this is just a
really important epic thing that you do.
If you're not using a custom build of
the engine, then just forget that engine
folder. Just do your project folder
there. And then inside of that project
folder is where you'll have your your
game project. And now what I add to this
is a dcc folder. So that stands for
digital content creation. So this is
where your Maya, Blender, uh, ProTools,
whatever, all of your art files or your
art project files go in there. And then
imports is this kind of middle ground
between your artist tools and your
engine tools. So this is where you'll
export the images, the textures, the FBX
files, that kind of stuff to bring into
the engine. And you'll see in a second
here why that is. So just to give you an
overview, we have the engine. All that
stuff goes in the engine folder. In the
project folder, this is where our
project is as well as our content. And
our plugins folder would also be here.
And then our dcc is where we have
Blender, Houdini, Maya, etc.
And then inside of those folders, you
might also further break it down by
scenes or characters or props. Or you
could do this the other way around. You
could have it organized first by scenes,
characters, items, and then have the
source files inside of that.
And then you have your imports. And so
this you could organize however you
want, perhaps by type of export, like
FBX's or images or audio.
And then inside of there, you can also
have your organization for your
different scenes, characters.
And so this is sort of an overview of
the whole thing, right? All right. And
I've grayed out the ones that should be

how are we doing on our three principles

Okay, great. I'm talking to the right

So, in P4, when you set up your mainline
stream, like I just showed you, it has
everything, right? It's got the engine
folder, the project folder, the uh dcc
tools, imports, all of that. What a
virtual stream is is it allows you to
make a filtered view. So, a virtual
stream that's a child of a mainline is
able to see up to everything the
mainline sees or possibly less. And then
if that has a child stream that could
see even less. The important thing here
is that a virtual stream doesn't get to
see more of the mainline than its parent
does. So it's kind of about like
progressively narrowing down what's
available when you work in that stream,
but all of them are in the same branch.
So even if I were all the way down here
in this bottom, you know, great
grandchild virtual stream and I edit a
file here, it's actually changing it in
all of these streams that can see it all
the way up to the main line, right? So
I'm still working all in one stream like
Epic likes, but I'm able to provide a
more manageable chunk of that for my
artists to work on. So let me show you
kind of what this looks like. So here I
have my main stream. You can see over on
the left side I've got all my files.
And now I'm going to make a new stream
from that main stream.
And in this case, uh, we'll have this be
for our 3D art.
Uh, let's just call it 3D art.
And then down here, I'm going to change
it to virtual type stream. And so now
when I go to the advanced tab, there's
this share paths here. And in this this
shared dot dot dot means everything. But
I can type in specific files or specific
folders here. So in this case, I want to
share that dcclender.
And let's share dcc/ Houdini.
Let's do Maya as well.
Uh, we can share Z dcccc
ZBrush
slash dot dot dot and that slash dot dot

all of its subfolders, right? It's a
recursive wild card. Uh, and then we
also want to add those imports folders
because when the artists are working on
it, when they export their FBX's,
they're going to put it into this
imports/meshes
folder. And then same with textures,

in there. And you'll see why that part
is important in a sec here. So when I
hit okay,
I now have this virtual stream down

now let's make another one. This one's

Same thing, we'll go into path. And here

music and dcc is reaper is the dcc I'm

So now you can see I've got these two
virtual streams. And so when someone
comes along to work in one or the other,
they're only going to get those paths
that we predefined. So it means they're
having to sync much less. It's going to
sync the files much faster because
they're only getting the files they
need. And then if you want to make this
a little bit easier because that's kind

you can add custom tools. If you go up

This can be anything you want. These

scripts, Python scripts, executable
files, whatever you want. And all you

some options. So I give it a name. I can

want a terminal window, and then this
add to context menus, I can select from

stream percent T. And if I have that add
to applicable context menus checked,
what that means is that when I

Um, and what this does is it's actually

So the whole idea here is that I want
people to feel empowered to use virtual
streams so that they can really easily
compartmentalize things when you're
passing stuff off to your artists. So
they only get what they need. And then
you could even make child streams off of
these. And like I said, a a virtual
stream can only see up to what its
parent sees, but it could see less. So
underneath 3D, we could have a stream
just for one character or you could have
a stream just for one scene or just for
one user. Like I could make one for
myself and then I could use that stream
utility or I could even update manually
if I wanted to so that I'm only ever
getting the files that I want. So
especially for people working remotely
on home internet connections, this can
be a lifesaver to realize that I only
need to get just the files I need and
not everything in the project. But I'm
still working on the same files in the
